title: Fundamentals of Credit Management
headline: This free online course will provide the knowledge required to manage credit and set effective payment conditions.
description: This 'Fundamentals of Credit Management' course explores the best credit management techniques to help your customers. It teaches lending principles, setting terms and the various types of borrowers. In addition, this course teaches you how to analyse income statements, examine and interpret ratios like liquidity and solvency ratios and learn about working capital loans and appraisal loan terms. Enrol today!

courseDescription:
We have designed this course to help credit managers find worthy borrowers and set practical credit repayment terms and conditions. This course begins with the basics of credit management: checking the borrower's credentials, capital and character, which will help you understand their willingness and capacity to repay the credit. Then you will learn the role of the credit officer, including analysing and verifying all data provided by the borrower, undertaking due diligence at each step and evaluating the underlying risk of financing before making a final decision. Next, we will introduce you to the principles of lending. Investigate the banking risks and their types, including liquidity, credit or default, operation and strategic risks. Learn about due diligence and various types of borrowers, including individual borrowers, partnership firms and the Hindu Undivided Family (HUF).

The following section introduces the income statement and its importance in the business. It includes detailed information about the business's income stream during the year, a list of expenses made by the company during the period and an analysis of the income statement. Next, you will learn about a business's work operating cycle, which can be either gross or net. You will also learn about ratios, defined as ‘the relationship between two variables’. We categorise ratios into four types. These include turnover, solvency and profitability ratios, which measure the capacity of the concerned to earn profits. Finally, you will learn about working capital loans which could be fund-based support in cash or non-fund based. Calculate the drawing power. Research depreciation and the role of the debt service coverage ratio in ensuring the borrower meets his debt obligations.

Credit management entails finding and verifying a borrower's worthiness, setting the terms on which the credit is granted, recovering the credit when the time is due and ensuring strict compliance with company credit policy. Credit management will improve the cash flow and reduce the rate of late credit payments in the company. By taking this course, you will gain the necessary knowledge and skills to manage credit, which will help you maintain strong cash flow in the company and obtain security interests where necessary. This course will boost your career and company. Why are you waiting? Take this course today and acquire a new skill.

Start Course Now

All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Principles of Lending and Types of Borrowers
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to credit management, you will learn the roles of a credit officer which includes finding quality borrowers, you will also learn how banks risk zones and you will be taught negative future risks can be mitigated suing due diligence, you will learn about the hybrid companies and important features of a company.
topics: Principles of Lending and Types of Borrowers - Learning Outcomes
Principles of Lending and Types of Borrowers - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Understanding Financial Statements, Balance Sheets and Ratio Analysis
modules.description: In this module, you will be taught the importance of an income statement in any business or company and you will learn how to analyze and interpret an income statement, you will be introduced to ratio analysis and its types which includes liquidity ratio and solvency ratio and you will also learn how it helps investors make the right investment.
topics: Financial Statements and Ratio Analysis - Learning Outcome
Financial Statements and Ratio Analysis - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Working Capital Loan and Appraisal of Term Loan
modules.description: In this module, you will learn the concept of working capital loan and working capital cycle and you will be introduced to term loans where you will learn about the depreciation of assets and also how banks draw up repayment schedules, you will also learn about term loan proposals and how to access proposals.
topics: Working Capital Loan and Loan Term Appraisal - Learning Outcomes
Working Capital Loan and Loan Term Appraisal  - Lesson Summary

• Learning Outcomes

  • By the end of this module, you will be able to
    • Explain the principles of lending in businesses.
    • Discuss the principles of risk spread.
    • State the importance of timely repayment of loans.
    • Summarize the major benefits of diversification.
    • Explain the goals of financial management.
    • Identify some of the borrowing powers of a company.
    • Recall the number of directors in a public company.
    • State the circumstances that lead to the dissolving of the partnership firm.

  • Types of Borrowers

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

    • The credit officer has to understand the creditworthiness of the borrower and their business in detail and then analyze and verify all data provided by the borrower, undertake due diligence at each step, evaluate the underline risk of financing and then make a final decision.
    • A risk is an uncertain event that may have a negative or positive impact on a business project, risk management involves identifying the risks, quantifying the risk, and also having a risk management response.
    • There are six types of banking risks, they are liquidity risk, credit or default risk, operation risk, strategic risk, market risk, and reputational risk.
    • A charge is a right created by any borrower on its assets and properties, present and future, in favor of a bank that has agreed to extend financial assistance.
    • A tangible asset is a physical asset while an intangible asset is vice versa, banks normally don’t accept nontangible assets as security for loans.
    • Individual borrowers come to the bank for two reasons, the first is to request a consumption loan while the second is to request a business loan.
    • Some of the important features of a company include a separate entity, perpetuity, separate property, and a common seal.
    • A company can borrow only after obtaining the certificate of the commencement of business from the registrar and also explicit mention of the power to borrow in the memoranda of the association.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • By the end of this module, you will be able to:  
    • Identify the various components of a financial statement.
    • Define stock turnover ratio and list the types implored in businesses.
    • Recall the formulas for calculating quick assets and net working capital.
    • State the primary function of the income statement.
    • Explain the importance of ratio analysis in a business.
    • State the objective of calculating the debt service coverage ratio.

  • Understanding Income Statement

  • Introduction to Ratios

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

    • An income statement is a document that gives well-detailed information about the income stream of the business during the year and also provides a list of expenses made by the business during the period.
    • Cost of sale is the summation of the direct costs for producing the goods that are sold by the company while the cost of production is the cost incurred to only producing the goods.
    • A ratio is a relationship between two variables, one on the numerator and the other on the denominator, which is created in a logical way so that it can enable investors to make meaningful decisions.
    • Ratios are categorized into four parts, these include the liquidity ratio, solvency ratios, turnover ratios, and the profitability ratio.
    • Liquidity of a business refers to the ability of the business to pay off short-term expenses and short-term liabilities or the ability of the current assets to pay off current liabilities.
    • The solvency ratios are also called the capital structure ratios, it relates to looking at the capital structure of the business, as to how much of the loan it has taken, and what is the extent of the owner’s contribution to the business.
    • Turnover ratios refer to the efficiency of the working capital cycle which is directly related to the profitability of the organization
    • Profitability ratios are important for stakeholders, this ratio measures the capacity of the concerned to earn profits which is different from actual profit. It can be related to the return of sales or the return of investment.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • By the end of this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the principles of the working capital loan system.
    • Distinguish between the gross and net operating cycle.
    • Define the term liquid surplus as used in computing working capital.
    • State the objectives of calculating the debt service coverage ratio.
    • Explain how to work out the debt service coverage ratio.
    • Recall the formula for calculating the break-even of a firm.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Working capital loans are provided by banks to fund the working capital shortage of the borrowers, they could be fund-based support in the form of cash and also in non-based which could be in the form of a letter of credit or letter guarantee.
    • Banks conduct a detailed assessment and provide a cash credit sanction with certain terms and conditions, the sanction letter provides a maximum limit and also a margin requirement on stocks and receivables by the borrowers, it also prescribes how the drawing power will be calculated.
    • The drawing power is calculated on the value of the stocks statement and the debtor's list provided every month.
    • A term loan is meant to acquire capital assets of the firm which are deployed to generate revenues for the business or company. The assets could be land or buildings and are long-term assets and they are usually very costly.
    • Depreciation is an accounting method of calculating the losses on fixed assets over a long period of time.
    • DSCR is an abbreviation for debt service coverage ratio, it is a tool to appraise the overall repayment capacity of the borrower to meet his debt obligations. There are two types of DSCR, the first is the gross DSCR, this measures the firm’s ability to repay the total debt obligation, and net DSCR
    • The total project cost includes the one-time cost and also the recurring cost which are necessary for starting the business.
